thread.title: Artist re-imagines iconic landmarks with paper cutouts
thread.title_full: Artist re-imagines iconic landmarks with paper cutouts

title: Artist re-imagines iconic landmarks with paper cutouts
text:
Artist re-imagines iconic landmarks with paper cutouts Last updated 11:27, October 20 2015 RichMcCor/Instagram 
Artist Rich McCor transforms Paris' Arc de Triomphe into a menacing Lego Man 
A 28-year-old artist has brought a bit of fun to some of the world's most iconic landmarks - simply by using a black piece of paper and a pair of scissors. 
Londoner Rich McCor has turned the Arc de Triomphe into a menacing Lego Man, the London Eye into a bicycle and even given Denmark's Little Mermaid statue her own selfie-stick. 
McCor, who shares his work on his Instagram account paperboyo , transforms the iconic backdrops by using clever cutouts. A photo posted by Rich McCor (@paperboyo) on Jul 9, 2015 at 2:26pm PDT 
Speaking to The Daily Mail . McCor said: "Some of the cut outs are pretty basic so don't take too long but for the tricky ones I'll just put on my headphones and crack on with it. 
'It's incredibly therapeutic, although at times it's equally tedious. 
"I would love to somehow make this hobby into a career, and if it involves travelling to places to shoot these images then that would be a dream come true." 
McCor's creative journey began when he started taking pictures of his work. He was then approached by Great Little Place London , who challenged him to design 10 photographs for them. 
Since starting the project, McCor has also learned a lot about the history of each landmark, information he also shares on his Instagram account.
